title: 110_hr3469
content: The Act titled "America's Border Security Act of 2007" includes provisions related to technological assets. The Act "America's Border Security Act of 2007" mandates increased use of Department of Defense equipment like unmanned aerial vehicles for surveillance at US borders to prevent illegal immigration. A report assessing risks and current equipment use must be submitted to Congress within 6 months. The Act mandates increased use of Department of Defense equipment for border surveillance, including a pilot program for unmanned aerial vehicles along the US-Canada border. No alteration to the prohibition on using Army or Air Force as a posse comitatus is allowed. Authorization of appropriations is provided. Authorization of appropriations is provided for the Secretary of Homeland Security for fiscal years 2008 through 2012 to carry out border surveillance activities. The Secretary of Homeland Security is authorized to construct all-weather roads, acquire vehicle barriers, and facilities for border control. Quarterly progress reports to Congress are required. Appropriations are authorized for fiscal years 2008 through 2012. Additionally, the Secretary can construct new ports of entry and improve existing ones. The Secretary of Homeland Security is tasked with developing a plan to enhance satellite communication for Border Patrol agents and other security agencies. Additionally, the use of unmanned aerial vehicles is addressed. The Secretary of Homeland Security is required to acquire and maintain at least 5 unmanned aerial vehicles and related equipment for patrolling the US international borders. Appropriations are authorized for fiscal years 2008 and 2009 for this purpose. Additionally, surveillance technologies programs are addressed. The Secretary of Homeland Security must develop and implement an aerial surveillance program using unmanned aerial vehicles to enhance border security with Canada and Mexico. The goal is continuous monitoring of each mile of the international borders. The Secretary of Homeland Security must develop an aerial surveillance program using various technologies to address border threats, consulting with the Secretary of Defense and the FAA for implementation. The program will include the use of aerial surveillance technologies in different terrains and areas. The Secretary of Homeland Security is evaluating surveillance technologies for border security in various terrains and areas, including near international borders. The assessment includes the effectiveness, cost, liability, safety, and privacy concerns of these technologies. Aerial surveillance technologies can continue to be used while their effectiveness is being assessed. The Secretary of Homeland Security can continue using aerial surveillance technologies while evaluating their effectiveness. A report must be submitted to Congress within 180 days, including program details and recommendations for improvement. Authorization of appropriations is available for this program. Additionally, the Secretary is required to establish a program for procuring additional surveillance technologies to achieve operational control. The Integrated and Automated Surveillance Program aims to use various technologies like vehicles, cameras, sensors, and satellites to establish a "virtual fence" along US international borders for border security. The program components include integrating technologies for automated surveillance, ensuring cameras do not need manual operation, and allowing for flexible camera views and positions. The Integrated and Automated Surveillance Program utilizes cameras that do not require manual operation, have flexible views and positions, and allow surveillance video to be viewed at multiple centers. A standard process is used to collect intrusion data, integrate future technology upgrades, and develop performance measures to evaluate effectiveness in detecting illegal intrusions along US borders. Plans are in place to streamline site selection and environmental assessment processes to minimize delays. The Integrated and Automated Surveillance Program aims to streamline site selection, validation, and environmental assessment processes for installing surveillance technology infrastructure. Standards are developed to expand shared use of existing structures and deploy nonpermanent or mobile surveillance platforms. The Secretary of Homeland Security must report to Congress on the Program's implementation within one year, including recommendations for enhancement. The Secretary will report on the Integrated and Automated Surveillance Program, including recommendations for improvement. The Secretary of Homeland Security will establish standards to evaluate contractors providing goods or services for the program. The Inspector General will review contracts over $5,000,000 to ensure compliance with cost requirements, performance objectives, and schedules. The Inspector General will report findings to the Secretary of Homeland Security regarding reviews conducted on contracts over $5,000,000. The Secretary must then submit a report to the Senate and House Committees on Homeland Security within 30 days, detailing findings and planned responses. Authorization of appropriations is provided for this subsection. SEC. 8. HIRING AND TRAINING OF BORDER AND TRANSPORTATION SECURITY PERSONNEL. During fiscal year 2008, the Secretary of Homeland Security is required to increase the number of full-time agents and support staff in the Bureau of Immigration and Customs Enforcement by 400, and in the Bureau of Customs and Border Protection by 600. The Secretary is authorized to waive any limitations on personnel numbers to meet these requirements. Ongoing training will be provided to ensure proficiency levels of personnel in utilizing new technologies to protect the borders of the United States. The Secretary of Homeland Security must annually prepare and submit a National Border Security Plan to Congress by January 31. The plan includes a vulnerability assessment of each port of entry on the northern and southern borders, with the option to establish port security coordinators for assistance.
